faqs.question: What happens at the first visit?
faqs.answer: We listen to goals, capture scans or photos if helpful, and outline options with straightforward next steps.

faqs.question: Do you show previews before treatment?
faqs.answer: Whenever possible we use visual planning so you can see movement, shaping, or shade shifts before committing.

faqs.question: How do payments work?
faqs.answer: We share estimates early, support staged payments, and provide receipts or documentation you may need.

sections.title: Composite bonding for measured smile refinement
sections.copy: Composite bonding (also called cosmetic bonding or dental bonding) uses layered resin to rebuild edges and balance shapes with minimal drilling. We preserve enamel wherever possible, plan conservatively, and keep results reversible.
bullets: Tooth-preserving contouring with light surface preparation
Resins layered to match shade, translucency, and texture
Calm appointment pacing with time for review before final polishing

sections.title: Where composite bonding can help
items: Can often be used to tidy chipped or worn incisal edges
Closes small gaps and black triangles in suitable cases
Refines tooth shape and proportions after orthodontic alignment
Balances a single tooth without committing to a full smile makeover

sections.label: Digital planning
sections.title: Digitally planned and guided bonding
sections.copy: We start with 3D scans and photographs, design the proposed changes digitally, and share mock-ups so you can preview the direction. Guided placement and finishing maps keep the resin precise and consistent.
sections.mediaHint: Digital smile planning and mock-up visuals

sections.title: Injection-moulded composite for controlled changes
sections.copy: For patients seeking the highest level of precision, we also offer injection moulded composite. The smile is digitally designed, a guide is produced, and resin is delivered through the guide to keep widths, edge lengths, and symmetry accurate.
bullets: Useful for smile widening and lengthening without aggressive preparation
Guided delivery to manage black triangles and embrasure form
Supports symmetry when planning alongside whitening or aligners

sections.title: How composite bonding fits with other options
items: When colour is the main concern, dentist-led whitening is usually recommended before bonding so shades align
If teeth are rotated or crowded, aligners or other orthodontic treatment can set the foundation before cosmetic bonding
For larger shape changes or durability, porcelain veneers or digitally designed 3D veneers may be more appropriate
Composite bonding often forms part of an Align → Bleach → Composite pathway, with veneers reserved for specific needs

sections.title: Longevity, maintenance, and repairs
items: With routine care, composite bonding can remain stable for several years; polish can be refreshed without replacing the whole restoration
Repairs are possible if chips occur, keeping intervention conservative
Good hygiene, reduced staining foods, and regular reviews help maintain colour and gloss
We discuss realistic wear expectations so you know when refinements may be needed

sections.title: Who composite bonding suits best
items: Patients wanting cosmetic improvement without irreversible drilling
Those planning staged care such as whitening or orthodontic alignment before final bonding
People exploring a cost-effective step before considering porcelain veneers
Patients who value reversible changes and measured maintenance

sections.title: Plan a calm, dentist-led bonding consultation
sections.strapline: We assess your teeth, discuss how whitening or aligners may fit, and tailor composite bonding to your goals.

sections.title: Injection-moulded composite for guided precision
sections.copy: Injection moulded composite is a digitally planned approach to cosmetic bonding. We design the smile change first, create a custom guide, and deliver the composite through it so widths, edges, and symmetry follow the plan without unnecessary drilling.
bullets: Digitally designed smile plan agreed before treatment
Custom guide helps composite follow planned shapes
Minimal tooth preparation to keep treatment reversible

sections.title: Where injection-moulded composite is useful
items: Smile widening with controlled arch form
Lengthening worn or uneven incisal edges
Closing small gaps and managing black triangles
Improving symmetry when several teeth are treated together
Providing predictable edge positions after orthodontic alignment

sections.label: Digital design
sections.title: Digitally planned, guide-delivered composite
sections.copy: We start with scans and photographs, map proposed changes with digital smile design, and share previews where helpful. A guide is produced from this plan so the composite is placed and finished against a defined blueprint, keeping the process controlled and repeatable while still relying on clinician judgement.
sections.mediaHint: Digital smile design, guide fabrication, and preview mock-ups

sections.title: Injection moulding and freehand composite
items: Freehand composite bonding remains excellent for single teeth and nuanced texture work
Injection moulding is chosen when symmetry and edge positions must match across several teeth
Guide-based delivery reduces guesswork without removing the need for skilled finishing
Both techniques sit within our cosmetic bonding toolkit and are selected case by case

sections.title: Reversibility, repairs, and maintenance
items: Composite placement is additive and generally keeps drilling minimal
Repairs or refinements can usually be made without starting again
Regular hygiene, polishing, and mindful diet choices help maintain gloss and shade
Longevity is discussed at consultation so you know how to look after guided composite work

sections.title: Injection-moulded composite and veneers
items: Porcelain veneers may offer greater long-term surface durability
Injection-moulded composite is reversible and often suited to staged cosmetic treatment
Patients considering veneers can trial digitally planned shapes with composite first
Upgrades to porcelain or digitally designed 3D veneers remain available later if appropriate

sections.title: Who benefits from guided composite bonding
items: Patients wanting precision changes with minimal intervention
People weighing veneers but preferring a reversible option
Those seeking digitally planned outcomes after whitening or orthodontic alignment
Detail-oriented patients who value predictable symmetry

sections.title: Plan an injection-moulded composite consultation
sections.strapline: We review your teeth, discuss how composite bonding, veneers, whitening, or alignment fit together, and build a guided plan that matches your goals.

dental_bridges.label: Dental bridges
dental_bridges.description: Fixed replacements for missing teeth planned with careful case selection and maintenance.

dental_crowns.label: Dental crowns
dental_crowns.description: Protective, tooth-preserving crowns planned with digital scans and calm appointments.

sections.title: Teeth whitening in Shoreham-by-Sea
sections.copy: Dentist-led home whitening with UK-compliant gels, custom trays, and clear shade planning. We keep enamel safe while preparing your smile for wider cosmetic work such as alignment or bonding.
bullets: Custom-fit trays made from digital scans
UK-appropriate gels prescribed and monitored by your dentist
Shade targets that respect your natural enamel and restorations
Planned as part of Align, Bleach, Composite smile design

sections.title: Safe, planned brightening with clear guardrails
items: UK-permitted gels selected for your enamel and gum health
Custom trays that protect soft tissues and deliver even gel coverage
Shade mapping and photography to track change without over-bleaching
Advice on how whitening interacts with veneers, crowns, and fillings
Follow-up built around hygiene visits and wider cosmetic plans

sections.title: A measured plan tailored to your smile
sections.copy: We assess enamel, existing restorations, and gum health before prescribing a gel strength and schedule. You’ll see a realistic shade range, understand how whitening supports planned alignment or bonding, and know when we’ll review progress.
bullets: Clinical exam and baseline shade recording
Digital scans for precise tray production
Discussion of ideal shade within safe limits
Guidance if veneers or composites are part of your plan
Clear timing for reviews and maintenance

sections.label: Technology
sections.title: Digital records and lab-made trays
sections.copy: We use calibrated photography, digital scans, and lab-made trays to keep gel placement accurate. Shade mapping documents progress and informs any adjustments to pacing or gel strength.

faqs.question: Is dentist-led whitening safe?
faqs.answer: Yes. We prescribe UK-compliant gels, design protective trays, and pace treatment so enamel stays healthy.

faqs.question: How long does treatment take?
faqs.answer: Most plans take a few weeks of at-home use with review points. Timing depends on your starting shade and goals.

faqs.question: Will whitening change crowns or veneers?
faqs.answer: Existing crowns, veneers, and fillings do not lighten. We plan around them and discuss refresh options if needed.

sections.title: Start with a whitening consultation
sections.strapline: Plan a calm, dentist-led whitening routine or pair it with wider smile design.

sections.title: Custom home whitening with dentist oversight
sections.copy: A calm, paced whitening plan using custom trays and prescribed gel strengths. We keep change gradual, stable, and respectful of your enamel and existing restorations.
bullets: Bespoke trays from your digital scans
UK-compliant gels chosen for your needs
Shade planning that fits with aligners or bonding
Check-ins to balance results and comfort

sections.title: Whitening planned around your teeth and gums
items: Prescription-only gels supplied with clear usage guidance
Trays designed to protect gum tissue and avoid spillage
Shade checks before, during, and after treatment
Sensitivity protocols with pacing and desensitising gel
Notes on how whitening will sit alongside crowns or veneers

sections.title: Measured home whitening without guesswork
sections.copy: We check enamel health, record your starting shade, and take scans for trays. Your dentist prescribes a gel strength, sets a nightly or alternate-day cadence, and aligns the plan with any upcoming cosmetic work.
bullets: Baseline photos and shade guide for reference
Tray fitting with instructions on gel placement
Advice on wear time and what to avoid
Review of existing fillings, crowns, or bonding
Planned review to confirm stability

sections.title: Steady steps to a brighter shade
items: Consultation and eligibility check
Digital scans and tray fabrication
Tray fit with first application guidance
Planned whitening sessions at home
Mid-plan review for shade and comfort
Final check and maintenance advice
sections.strapline: We keep communication open so you know when to pause, adjust gel, or book a review.

sections.title: Comfort-first whitening
items: Temporary sensitivity is managed with pacing and desensitising care
Existing restorations will not change shade; we plan any refinements after whitening
Avoid strongly coloured foods or smoking during active treatment
We check fit and margins to prevent gum irritation
Long-term maintenance planned with your hygienist

faqs.question: How long will I wear the trays each day?
faqs.answer: Most patients whiten for a set period each evening based on the prescribed gel. We’ll agree the exact cadence with you.

faqs.question: What if my teeth feel sensitive?
faqs.answer: Tell us and pause for a day or two. We can adjust frequency, provide desensitising gel, or modify the plan.

faqs.question: Can I whiten if I have bonding or crowns?
faqs.answer: Yes, but those materials will not lighten. We plan whitening first and discuss refreshing restorations afterwards if needed.

sections.title: Set up your home whitening plan
sections.strapline: Book a dentist-led whitening assessment and tray fit.

sections.title: Keep your whitening results steady
sections.copy: Dentist-guided top-ups reuse your existing trays and follow a conservative schedule. We protect enamel, match refreshes to hygiene visits, and avoid over-whitening.
bullets: Tray checks to confirm fit before supplying gel
Top-up cadence tailored to coffee, wine, or lifestyle factors
Advice on timing with hygiene or other cosmetic steps
Monitoring to keep shade within a natural range

sections.title: A quick check before any refresh
sections.copy: We review your shade, tray fit, and any recent dental work before recommending more gel. This keeps maintenance aligned with your oral health and any planned bonding or veneer updates.
bullets: Shade comparison against your baseline
Inspection of trays for seal and comfort
Discussion of how often you’ll realistically top-up
Guidance if restorations need refreshing instead of whitening
Written instructions for the latest gel strength

sections.title: Refresh without starting from scratch
items: Book a review and shade check
Confirm tray fit and comfort
Agree a short, conservative top-up schedule
Use prescribed gel with your existing trays
Pause and check-in if sensitivity appears
Align future top-ups with routine visits
sections.strapline: Top-ups are calibrated to your lifestyle so results stay natural, not artificial.

faqs.question: How often should I top-up?
faqs.answer: Most patients refresh once or twice a year, often after hygiene visits. We tailor the schedule to your habits and starting shade.

faqs.question: Can I reuse my old trays?
faqs.answer: Yes, provided the fit is still secure. We’ll check for wear or gaps before supplying gel.

faqs.question: Will I need stronger gel each time?
faqs.answer: Usually not. We stick to safe, regulated strengths and keep to the smallest effective dose for your goals.

sections.title: Schedule a maintenance review
sections.strapline: Refresh your whitening plan with dentist guidance and the trays you already have.

sections.title: Whitening with sensitivity in mind
sections.copy: We plan whitening for sensitive teeth using gentle gel strengths, protective trays, and pacing. Every step is monitored by your dentist so comfort leads the plan.
bullets: Suitability check to rule out underlying causes
Custom trays that limit gel contact with gums
UK-regulated gels selected for comfort
Pacing and breaks built in to reduce flare-ups

sections.title: Designed to be tolerable for sensitive teeth
items: Assessment for cracks, recession, or decay before starting
Desensitising toothpaste or gel recommended ahead of whitening
Lower, regulated gel strengths with clinician oversight
Guidance on shorter wear times and gradual pacing
Follow-up to adjust if tingling or zingers appear

sections.title: Staying comfortable during whitening
items: We pause treatment if sensitivity spikes and restart with changes
Avoid very hot, cold, or acidic foods during active whitening
Use desensitising products as advised between sessions
Existing restorations will not lighten; we plan around them
Report any sharp sensations so we can adjust or review

faqs.question: Why can whitening feel sensitive?
faqs.answer: Whitening gels can temporarily increase fluid movement within the tooth. We control gel strength and contact time to keep this minimal.

faqs.question: Can I still whiten if I already feel sensitivity?
faqs.answer: Often yes, once we rule out decay or cracks. We may start slower, use desensitising support, and space applications further apart.

faqs.question: What should I do if I feel a zing?
faqs.answer: Pause for a day or two and let us know. We can adjust frequency, recommend relief products, or review fit.

sections.title: Plan whitening that respects sensitivity
sections.strapline: Book a review so we can tailor gel strength, pacing, and aftercare to your comfort.

sections.title: Dentist-led answers about whitening
sections.copy: Clear, UK-compliant guidance on whitening safety, shade expectations, and how treatment fits with veneers or crowns.
bullets: Honest limits on shade change
What to expect with existing restorations
How whitening supports smile makeovers
Steps to keep results stable

faqs.question: Does whitening damage teeth?
faqs.answer: When prescribed and monitored by a dentist using UK-regulated gels, whitening is safe for enamel. We assess for decay or gum issues first and use protective trays.

faqs.question: How white can teeth go?
faqs.answer: We aim for a natural, even shade that suits your skin tone and enamel. Shade maps set a realistic range so we avoid over-whitening.

faqs.question: Does whitening affect veneers or crowns?
faqs.answer: Existing crowns, veneers, and fillings will not lighten. We plan whitening first, then match or refresh restorations if needed.

faqs.question: How long does whitening last?
faqs.answer: Results are maintained with good hygiene and occasional top-ups. We’ll guide you on a safe refresh schedule using your existing trays.

faqs.question: Is whitening part of a smile makeover?
faqs.answer: Often yes. Whitening is the “B” in our Align, Bleach, Composite approach so colour is set before aligning teeth or adding bonding.

sections.title: Plan whitening with a dentist
sections.strapline: Ask your questions in person and receive a tailored whitening plan.

sections.title: Smile makeovers guided by a shared plan
sections.copy: We map veneers, whitening, aligners, or restorations into one coordinated plan with clear checkpoints.
bullets: Plan designed from scans and photos
Sequence options reviewed together
Checkpoints keep outcomes aligned

sections.label: Plan canvas
sections.title: Preview the makeover path
sections.copy: A visual map shows phases, materials, and timing so you know what happens when.

sections.label: Planning tools
sections.title: Tools that keep complex plans clear
sections.copy: Each tool keeps the makeover coordinated and transparent.

items.title: Digital smile design
items.description: Aligns proportions and material choices before we start.

items.title: Phase timeline
items.description: Lays out aligner, veneer, or whitening steps with review points.

items.title: Photo and scan tracking
items.description: We log progress to keep adjustments on-plan.

sections.label: Clinician insight
sections.quote: A clear roadmap means every stage—alignment, colour, restorations—stays coordinated and calm.

stories.summary: Combined aligners and whitening with clear checkpoints.
stories.name: Case P

stories.summary: Reviewed veneer mock-ups before printing finals.
stories.name: Case Q

stories.summary: Tracked each phase with photos to stay aligned to the plan.
stories.name: Case R

faqs.question: How is the plan built?
faqs.answer: We combine scans, photos, and goals to set phases for alignment, whitening, and restorations.

faqs.question: Can we adjust along the way?
faqs.answer: Checkpoints let us refine timing or materials while staying on-plan.

faqs.question: How do I follow the phases?
faqs.answer: A shared roadmap outlines what happens next and when review visits are scheduled.

sections.title: Plan a full smile makeover
sections.strapline: Book a planning session or preview a digital roadmap.

sections.title: Calm, prompt support when something feels urgent
sections.copy: We make time for same-day emergencies, guide you on what to do next, and keep language calm and practical. If you are in pain, bleeding, or have a sudden change to a tooth or restoration, contact us so we can prioritise your visit.
bullets: Clear triage to decide if you need immediate or urgent care
Advice on protecting a tooth or restoration before you arrive
Appointments that focus on settling pain and stabilising the area
Follow-up planning once things feel safe again

sections.title: Emergency, urgent, or routine?
items: Emergency: severe pain, significant bleeding, facial swelling, or a knocked-out tooth
Urgent: broken, chipped, or lost restorations without major pain
Routine: minor sensitivity or small chips that can wait for a scheduled visit
Unsure: call us and we will help decide the right pace

sections.title: What to do now
items: Call the practice so we can triage and reserve time for you
Keep the area clean with gentle rinsing; avoid very hot or cold foods
Store any broken fragment or restoration in a clean container
Use pharmacy pain relief if needed and safe for you, following the packet instructions
If a tooth is knocked out, keep it moist in milk or saliva and bring it with you

sections.label: Supportive care
sections.title: Stabilise first, then plan comfortable follow-up
sections.copy: We focus on easing pain, protecting the area, and explaining what to expect next. If further treatment is needed, we discuss options in plain language so you can choose the right pace.

faqs.question: How quickly can I be seen?
faqs.answer: We reserve time for emergencies each day. Call as soon as you can so we can confirm the earliest slot and share any immediate advice.

faqs.question: Is emergency care different from a routine visit?
faqs.answer: Emergency appointments focus on stabilising and relieving pain. Follow-up visits handle any longer-term treatment once you are comfortable.

faqs.question: What if I am unsure it is an emergency?
faqs.answer: Contact us and describe what you are feeling or seeing. We will advise whether you need to come in urgently or schedule a routine visit.

sections.title: Call for emergency dental care
sections.strapline: Tell us what has happened so we can guide you and reserve the right appointment time.

sections.title: Same-day appointments when something can’t wait
sections.copy: If you are in pain, have swelling, or have damaged a tooth, we prioritise getting you seen. We’ll stabilise the area, ease discomfort, and plan the next steps together.
bullets: Phone triage to book the right appointment length
Advice on caring for the area before you arrive
Focus on relief and stabilisation first
Clear follow-up plan once you are comfortable

sections.title: When to book an emergency appointment
items: Severe or escalating toothache
Swelling in the face or gums
Broken teeth or restorations causing pain
Bleeding that does not settle
Knocked-out or loose teeth after an accident

sections.title: How to prepare
items: Call us and describe what happened so we can schedule you appropriately
Avoid eating on the affected side and keep the area clean
Bring any fragments, crowns, or fillings with you in a clean container
Use pharmacy pain relief if safe for you and follow the packet guidance

sections.title: Why timing matters
sections.copy: Seeing you quickly reduces discomfort, prevents problems from worsening, and helps us save or protect the tooth. Early care often means simpler treatment and calmer visits.
sections.label: Prompt care
What we can do
sections.title: Stabilise, soothe, and plan
sections.copy: Depending on what we find, we may provide temporary fillings, smooth sharp edges, adjust or re-fit a restoration, prescribe medication, or start definitive treatment once you are ready.

faqs.question: Can you always fix the problem on the day?
faqs.answer: We focus on relieving pain and protecting the area at the first visit. Some treatments are completed immediately; others may be staged once things are stable.

faqs.question: What if I am nervous about urgent treatment?
faqs.answer: We explain each step, use gentle techniques, and only move forward at a pace you are comfortable with.

faqs.question: Do I need a referral for an emergency visit?
faqs.answer: No referral is needed. Contact us directly and we will arrange an appointment based on your symptoms.

sections.title: Call for an emergency appointment
sections.strapline: Tell us what has happened so we can reserve time and guide you before you travel.

sections.title: Relief for severe toothache and sudden dental pain
sections.copy: Intense or throbbing pain can be unsettling. We triage quickly, keep explanations straightforward, and focus on making you comfortable while we identify the cause.
bullets: Calm assessment to pinpoint the source of pain
Gentle care to reduce sensitivity and inflammation
Medication or protective dressings where appropriate
Follow-up plan to prevent pain returning

sections.title: Common signs
items: Sharp, throbbing, or radiating pain
Sensitivity to hot, cold, or biting
Swelling around the tooth or face
Pain that wakes you at night
Discomfort after a recent filling or trauma

sections.title: What to do now
items: Contact us so we can arrange an emergency visit
Rinse gently with warm salty water to keep the area clean
Avoid extremes of temperature and chew on the opposite side
Use over-the-counter pain relief if suitable for you and follow the instructions
Do not place aspirin on the gum or tooth

sections.title: Why prompt care matters
sections.copy: Severe pain can indicate infection, a cracked tooth, or deep decay. Early attention helps us relieve discomfort quickly and protect the tooth or supporting tissues.
sections.label: Prompt relief
What we can do
sections.title: Ease pain and address the cause
sections.copy: Depending on the diagnosis, we may place a soothing dressing, adjust a restoration, clean an inflamed area, begin root canal care, or prescribe medication to settle infection.

faqs.question: Can I wait to see if the pain settles?
faqs.answer: If pain is severe or getting worse, contact us. Early care helps prevent complications and keeps treatment simpler.

faqs.question: Will treatment be painful?
faqs.answer: We use gentle techniques and numbing to make you comfortable. Let us know how you are feeling throughout the visit.

faqs.question: What if the pain starts overnight?
faqs.answer: Use appropriate pain relief if safe for you, avoid triggers such as hot or cold food, and call us first thing so we can book you in.

sections.title: Arrange urgent toothache care
sections.strapline: We will guide you on immediate steps and bring you in quickly to relieve pain.

sections.title: Support for dental abscesses and infections
sections.copy: Swelling, throbbing pain, or a bad taste can indicate infection. We act quickly to ease discomfort, manage the infection, and protect surrounding teeth and tissues.
bullets: Rapid assessment and drainage where appropriate
Medication guidance tailored to you
Advice on reducing pressure and irritation
Follow-up to complete definitive treatment

sections.title: What you might notice
items: Swelling of the gum or face
Persistent or throbbing pain
Bad taste or discharge
Fever or feeling unwell
Difficulty biting or opening

sections.title: What to do now
items: Call us urgently so we can arrange appropriate care
Avoid pressing on the swelling and keep the area clean
Rinse gently with warm salty water to reduce surface bacteria
Use pharmacy pain relief if suitable and stay hydrated
Seek immediate help if swelling affects breathing or vision

sections.title: Why swift treatment matters
sections.copy: Infections can spread and become more serious if left untreated. Early drainage or medication reduces pain and helps protect your overall health.
sections.label: Act early
What we can do
sections.title: Reduce infection and protect the tooth
sections.copy: We may drain the infection, adjust or open the tooth to relieve pressure, prescribe antibiotics when clinically appropriate, and plan root canal treatment or other care to resolve the cause.

faqs.question: Do I always need antibiotics?
faqs.answer: Not every abscess requires antibiotics. We assess you in person to decide the best approach, which may include drainage or other treatment.

faqs.question: Will the swelling go away on its own?
faqs.answer: Swelling often needs professional care. Contact us if you notice it, especially if pain or fever is present.

faqs.question: Can I work or travel after treatment?
faqs.answer: We will advise based on the procedure performed and how you feel. Many people can return to routine with simple aftercare guidance.

sections.title: Get help for swelling or infection
sections.strapline: Call now so we can assess and relieve the infection safely.

sections.title: Care for broken, chipped, or cracked teeth
sections.copy: A sudden chip or crack can be alarming. We smooth sharp edges, protect the tooth, and plan restorative options so you can eat and speak comfortably again.
bullets: Quick smoothing to prevent cuts to cheeks or tongue
Temporary coverings where needed
Assessment for structural stability
Clear plan for lasting repairs

sections.title: What you might notice
items: Sharp edges or roughness
Sensitivity to cold or air
Pain when biting
Visible crack lines
A missing piece of tooth

sections.title: What to do now
items: Save any broken fragment in clean water or milk
Avoid biting on the damaged tooth
Rinse gently to keep the area clean
Use dental wax or sugar-free chewing gum to cover a sharp edge if needed
Contact us promptly so we can protect the tooth

sections.title: Why prompt treatment matters
sections.copy: Acting quickly reduces the risk of the crack deepening, prevents irritation to the mouth, and helps us preserve as much natural tooth as possible.
sections.label: Protect the tooth
What we can do
sections.title: Stabilise and restore
sections.copy: Depending on the size and location of the damage, we may smooth the area, place a temporary cover, rebuild with composite bonding, fit a crown, or plan further treatment if the crack is deeper.

faqs.question: Can a chipped tooth wait?
faqs.answer: Small chips may seem minor but can lead to sensitivity or further damage. Contact us so we can advise on timing.

faqs.question: Will I need a crown straight away?
faqs.answer: Not always. We choose the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth strong, which may start with composite bonding or smoothing.

faqs.question: Is it safe to keep eating?
faqs.answer: Avoid chewing on the affected side until we assess the tooth. Softer foods and careful cleaning can help protect it in the meantime.

sections.title: Book care for a chipped or cracked tooth
sections.strapline: We will protect the tooth, relieve sensitivity, and plan the right repair.

sections.title: Urgent help for a knocked-out tooth
sections.copy: A tooth that has fully come out needs immediate attention. We guide you on how to handle the tooth, prepare the site, and increase the chances of saving it.
bullets: Clear instructions on storing the tooth
Priority appointments for avulsed teeth
Calm handling to protect the socket and root
Follow-up care to support healing

sections.title: What you might notice
items: A missing tooth after trauma
Bleeding or an empty socket
Swelling or tenderness around the area
Possible damage to nearby teeth or lips

sections.title: What to do immediately
items: Handle the tooth by the crown only; avoid touching the root
If dirty, gently rinse with cold running water for a few seconds—do not scrub
Place the tooth back into the socket if you can and bite gently on a clean cloth
If you cannot reinsert it, store it in milk or saliva (not water)
Call us straight away and travel to the practice

sections.title: Why speed is critical
sections.copy: The sooner a knocked-out tooth is replanted, the better the chance of long-term success. Delays can reduce survival of the tooth or affect surrounding tissues.
sections.label: Act quickly
What we can do
sections.title: Replant, stabilise, and protect
sections.copy: We clean and replant the tooth when appropriate, stabilise it with a splint, manage any injuries to nearby teeth, and discuss future options such as root canal therapy or replacement if needed.

faqs.question: Can a baby tooth be replanted?
faqs.answer: Baby teeth are not typically replanted. Contact us so we can assess and protect the area safely.

faqs.question: What if the tooth looks damaged?
faqs.answer: Bring it with you even if broken. We will determine whether replanting is possible or discuss other options.

faqs.question: Do I need a tetanus check?
faqs.answer: If the injury involved soil or uncertain contamination, we may suggest contacting your GP about tetanus status.

sections.title: Call immediately about a knocked-out tooth
sections.strapline: We will guide you on safe handling and prepare to see you right away.

sections.title: Support for lost crowns, veneers, or fillings
sections.copy: If a restoration comes loose or falls out, we protect the exposed tooth, ease any sensitivity, and plan a secure repair or replacement.
bullets: Clean, careful assessment of the exposed tooth
Temporary coverage when needed
Discussion on repair versus replacement
Guidance on protecting the tooth until fixed

sections.title: What you might notice
items: A missing crown, veneer, or filling
Sensitivity to hot or cold
Rough or sharp edges
Food catching in the exposed area
Change in how your bite feels

sections.title: What to do now
items: Keep the restoration if you have it and bring it to your appointment
Avoid chewing on the exposed tooth
Rinse after eating to keep the area clean
Do not attempt to glue the restoration back yourself
Call us so we can arrange a prompt visit

sections.title: Why prompt attention helps
sections.copy: Exposed tooth surfaces can become sensitive or decay if left uncovered. Seeing you quickly keeps the tooth protected and makes re-fitting or replacing smoother.
sections.label: Protect exposed teeth
What we can do
sections.title: Secure, calm repairs
sections.copy: We assess whether the existing crown, veneer, or filling can be cleaned and re-bonded, place a temporary solution if needed, or plan a new restoration tailored to your bite and smile.

faqs.question: Can I eat before the appointment?
faqs.answer: Choose softer foods and avoid the affected side to prevent further damage or sensitivity.

faqs.question: Will you reuse my crown or veneer?
faqs.answer: If the restoration is suitable and fits well, we may re-bond it. Otherwise, we will plan a replacement and keep you comfortable in the meantime.

faqs.question: Is it urgent if I have no pain?
faqs.answer: Even without pain, an exposed tooth can deteriorate. Booking soon helps protect the tooth structure and your bite.

sections.title: Book help for a lost restoration
sections.strapline: We will protect the tooth, discuss repair options, and get you back to comfort.

sections.title: Care after dental trauma or accidents
sections.copy: Falls, sports injuries, or other accidents can affect teeth and soft tissues. We provide calm assessment, stop bleeding, protect damaged areas, and outline any further treatment.
bullets: Gentle checks for teeth, gums, and jaw
Advice on cleaning and swelling control
Temporary stabilisation if needed
Clear next steps for definitive care

sections.title: What you might notice
items: Bleeding from gums or lips
Loose or displaced teeth
Chips, cracks, or fractures
Cuts inside the mouth
Jaw soreness after impact

sections.title: What to do now
items: If bleeding, apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or gauze
Rinse with cool water to clear debris
Save any tooth fragments or restorations
Use a cold compress on the outside of the cheek to reduce swelling
Contact us promptly; seek urgent medical help if you suspect other injuries

sections.title: Why prompt assessment helps
sections.copy: Early evaluation lets us stabilise teeth, check for hidden fractures, and plan repairs before complications develop. It also helps us coordinate with medical teams if needed.
sections.label: Early checks
What we can do
sections.title: Stabilise and plan recovery
sections.copy: Treatment may include smoothing edges, splinting loose teeth, placing temporary coverings, prescribing medication, or coordinating imaging and follow-up restorative care.

faqs.question: Do I need X-rays after an accident?
faqs.answer: We will advise after examining the area. Imaging helps check for fractures or root damage that are not visible.

faqs.question: What if a tooth feels loose?
faqs.answer: Keep it clean, avoid wiggling it, and contact us. We may splint it to nearby teeth while it heals.

faqs.question: Can you help with mouth cuts?
faqs.answer: Yes. We assess soft tissue injuries, clean the area, and advise if medical attention or stitches are needed.

sections.title: Arrange care after dental trauma
sections.strapline: We will check for hidden issues, stabilise your teeth, and guide recovery.

sections.title: Prevention-first dentistry that keeps teeth for life
sections.body: Regular exams, calm explanations, and thoughtful hygiene support help you avoid problems and keep your smile comfortable for the long term.
bullets: Gentle, unhurried check-ups with the same clinical team
Prevention plans tailored to your enamel, gums, and lifestyle
Clear guidance if you’re anxious or prefer slower appointments

sections.title: Protect teeth before problems arise
items: Prevention-first mindset: preserve natural tooth structure wherever possible
Routine reviews that track subtle changes in enamel, gums, and bite
Comfort-focused care so you feel confident attending regularly
Advice that matches your habits, home care, and medical history
Clear onward pathways when you need restorative or specialist support

sections.title: Every check-up is detailed and documented
sections.body: We map your teeth, gums, and bite at each visit so we can spot issues early. Records are updated calmly with time for your questions.
bullets: Oral cancer screening at every check-up
Gum assessment to track inflammation or recession
Bite and jaw comfort review with referral to TMJ care when needed (/treatments/tmj-jaw-comfort)
Digital photos and scans where appropriate to monitor changes

sections.title: Professional hygiene that supports home care
items: Gentle, thorough cleaning to remove plaque and hardened tartar
Polishing and airflow-style finishing where suitable for stain control
Tips to improve brushing and interdental cleaning at home
Why visits matter even if you brush well: hidden build-up and hard-to-reach areas
Preventing gum disease and bad breath with tailored intervals—see periodontal care (/treatments/periodontal-gum-care)
sections.strapline: Regular hygiene keeps gums healthy and helps fillings, crowns, and implants last longer.

sections.title: Simple, science-led guidance you can follow
sections.body: We create a plan that fits your daily routine so small adjustments have a big impact.
bullets: Fluoride advice matched to your risk level—no pushy sales
Diet and sugar-frequency guidance with practical swaps
Support for sensitive teeth, including gentle techniques and desensitising care
Custom mouthguards for sport or grinding, with 3D-printed options (/treatments/3d-mouth-guards)

sections.title: Early detection keeps treatment simpler
items: Decay caught early before fillings or inlays are needed
Cracks, chips, and worn teeth monitored before they worsen
Gum problems identified before they require periodontal therapy
Bite changes spotted early to avoid premature wear
Clear onward paths if you ever need restorative care such as crowns, root canal, or extractions

sections.title: Care tailored to every stage
items: Children: gentle guidance on brushing habits, diet, and fissure sealant suitability
Teens and young adults: monitoring wisdom teeth, orthodontic retainers, and sports protection
Young-at-heart retirees: focus on comfort, function, and maintaining existing restorations
Medical changes considered so your plan stays safe and effective
Appointment pacing adjusted if you’re nervous or prefer slower visits

faqs.question: How often should I come?
faqs.answer: Most patients attend every 6 months, but we may suggest shorter or longer gaps based on gum health, decay risk, and how quickly plaque builds for you.

faqs.question: Do you check for mouth cancer?
faqs.answer: Yes. Oral cancer screening is part of every exam. We review soft tissues, lymph areas, and any changes you’ve noticed.

faqs.question: I’m nervous — can you go slowly?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Tell us ahead of time and we’ll pace the visit, explain each step, and link you to our nervous patient support if helpful (/treatments/nervous-patients).

faqs.question: Is home whitening better?
faqs.answer: Dentist-led whitening is usually safer and more predictable. We assess your teeth first and can advise on supervised home whitening through our whitening hub (/treatments/teeth-whitening).

sections.title: Book your comprehensive dental exam
sections.body: Speak to us about a prevention-first plan. If you’re anxious, tell us — we’ll tailor the visit and pace it carefully.

sections.title: Calm, thorough gum care to steady teeth and implants
sections.body: Healthy gums support every part of your smile. We explain the difference between gingivitis (reversible inflammation) and periodontitis (deeper bone loss), then tailor care that protects your teeth, implants, and confidence.
bullets: Full periodontal assessments with gentle charting and imaging
Non-surgical therapy focused on deep cleaning and root surface debridement
Personalised maintenance to keep gums, teeth, and implants stable

sections.title: Stable gums protect your bite and overall health
items: Healthy gums keep teeth and implants anchored and comfortable
Preventing inflammation supports fresher breath and everyday comfort
Evidence links uncontrolled gum disease with diabetes control and cardiovascular health
Care plans are judgement-free and paced to suit you

sections.title: Gingivitis vs periodontitis
sections.body: Gingivitis is surface-level inflammation that can usually be reversed with tailored cleaning and home care. Periodontitis affects the deeper support around teeth or implants, leading to pocketing and bone loss. Early, steady treatment limits damage and keeps treatment conservative.
bullets: We check for bleeding, plaque build-up, and gum measurements
X-rays or scans help us see bone levels where needed
You’ll receive a clear, written plan before any therapy

sections.title: What patients often notice
items: Bleeding gums, soreness, or bad breath that keeps returning
Gum recession, spacing changes, or teeth feeling slightly mobile
History of smoking, stress, diabetes, or family tendency to gum disease
Peri-implant inflammation such as redness or bleeding around implants

sections.title: Non-surgical care first, with clear reviews
items: Comprehensive assessment with periodontal charting and tailored photos/scans
Personalised home care coaching, including interdental cleaning and toothpaste advice
Root surface debridement (deep cleaning) with topical anaesthetic or local anaesthetic for comfort
Airflow-style stain removal or polishing where suitable after plaque and tartar are removed
Re-evaluation of pocket depths and gum response after healing
Supportive maintenance visits to keep disease stable; onward referral discussed for complex cases
sections.strapline: Most patients stabilise with non-surgical care and regular maintenance when we work together on habits and reviews.

sections.title: Modern hygiene tools with a gentle touch
sections.body: Ultrasonic scalers, fine hand instruments, and airflow-style finishing help remove plaque and calculus thoroughly. We use numbing gels or local anaesthetic when needed and share measured progress so you feel in control.

sections.title: Keeping gums healthy after treatment
items: Short-term tenderness or temperature sensitivity is common and settles with good home care
Smoking, unmanaged stress, or poorly controlled diabetes can slow healing — we’ll factor this into your plan
Regular supportive periodontal therapy to maintain pocket depth reductions
Clear instructions on cleaning around teeth and implants to protect results

sections.title: Answers to common gum care questions

faqs.question: Does deep cleaning hurt?
faqs.answer: Treatment is planned gently with numbing gels or local anaesthetic where needed. You’ll be guided on what to expect and how to keep things comfortable afterwards.

faqs.question: How long does it take to see improvement?
faqs.answer: Gums often look and feel healthier within weeks, but long-term stability depends on regular maintenance and the risk factors we identify together.

faqs.question: Can gum tissue grow back?
faqs.answer: Inflammation can reduce and pockets can tighten with good care. Recession usually needs protective maintenance rather than regrowth, and we’ll discuss options if grafting or referral is appropriate.

faqs.question: What about implants with gum inflammation?
faqs.answer: Peri-implant tissues can often be stabilised with careful cleaning, airflow-style stain removal, and close reviews. If advanced peri-implantitis is present, we’ll outline referral options calmly.

sections.title: Book a periodontal assessment
sections.body: Let’s map your gum health and plan steady, preventative care. Related care you may find helpful: Dental Implants (/treatments/implants), Preventative & General Dentistry (/treatments/preventative-and-general-dentistry), Dental check-ups & oral cancer screening (/treatments/preventative-and-general-dentistry), Nervous Patients (/treatments/nervous-patients).

implants.label: Dental Implants in Shoreham-by-Sea
implants.intro: Secure implant placement with guided planning and careful aftercare.

clear_aligners.label: Clear Aligners in Shoreham-by-Sea
clear_aligners.intro: Discreet, removable aligners planned digitally with regular check-ins.
